text: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them--all sorts of little
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand,
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good,
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them--'I wish they'd get the
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: trial done,' she thought, 'and hand round the refreshments!' But there
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: her, to pass away the time.
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: the name of nearly everything there. 'That's the judge,' she said to
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: herself, 'because of his great wig.'
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: 'And that's the jury-box,' thought Alice, 'and those twelve creatures,'
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: (she was obliged to say 'creatures,' you see, because some of them were
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: animals, and some were birds,) 'I suppose they are the jurors.' She said
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: age knew the meaning of it at all. However, 'jury-men' would have done
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: just as well.
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. 'What are they
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: doing?' Alice whispered to the Gryphon. 'They can't have anything to put
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: down yet, before the trial's begun.'
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: 'They're putting down their names,' the Gryphon whispered in reply, 'for
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.'
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: 'Stupid things!' Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, 'Silence in the court!' and the
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: was talking.
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders,
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: that all the jurors were writing down 'stupid things!' on their slates,
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: and she could even make out that one of them didn't know how to spell
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: 'stupid,' and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. 'A nice
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: muddle their slates'll be in before the trial's over!' thought Alice.
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and
title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

text: very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly

title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: My thanks are due in three quarters.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: To the Public, for the indulgent ear it has inclined to a plain tale with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: few pretensions.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: NOTE TO THE THIRD EDITION
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I avail myself of the opportunity which a third edition of "Jane Eyre"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: affords me, of again addressing a word to the Public, to explain that my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: claim to the title of novelist rests on this one work alone.  If,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: therefore, the authorship of other works of fiction has been attributed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to me, an honour is awarded where it is not merited; and consequently,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: denied where it is justly due.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: This explanation will serve to rectify mistakes which may already have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: been made, and to prevent future errors.

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: set: I should not like to go a begging."

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER V
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Five o'clock had hardly struck on the morning of the 19th of January,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: when Bessie brought a candle into my closet and found me already up and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: nearly dressed.  I had risen half-an-hour before her entrance, and had
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: washed my face, and put on my clothes by the light of a half-moon just
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: setting, whose rays streamed through the narrow window near my crib.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was to leave Gateshead that day by a coach which passed the lodge gates
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: at six a.m.  Bessie was the only person yet risen; she had lit a fire in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the nursery, where she now proceeded to make my breakfast.  Few children
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: can eat when excited with the thoughts of a journey; nor could I.  Bessie,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: having pressed me in vain to take a few spoonfuls of the boiled milk and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bread she had prepared for me, wrapped up some biscuits in a paper and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: put them into my bag; then she helped me on with my pelisse and bonnet,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and wrapping herself in a shawl, she and I left the nursery.  As we
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: passed Mrs. Reed's bedroom, she said, "Will you go in and bid Missis good-
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bye?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No, Bessie: she came to my crib last night when you were gone down to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: supper, and said I need not disturb her in the morning, or my cousins
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: either; and she told me to remember that she had always been my best
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: friend, and to speak of her and be grateful to her accordingly."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What did you say, Miss?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Nothing: I covered my face with the bedclothes, and turned from her to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the wall."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "That was wrong, Miss Jane."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "It was quite right, Bessie.  Your Missis has not been my friend: she has
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: been my foe."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "O Miss Jane! don't say so!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Good-bye to Gateshead!" cried I, as we passed through the hall and went
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: out at the front door.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The moon was set, and it was very dark; Bessie carried a lantern, whose
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: light glanced on wet steps and gravel road sodden by a recent thaw.  Raw
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and chill was the winter morning: my teeth chattered as I hastened down
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the drive.  There was a light in the porter's lodge: when we reached it,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: we found the porter's wife just kindling her fire: my trunk, which had
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: been carried down the evening before, stood corded at the door.  It
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wanted but a few minutes of six, and shortly after that hour had struck,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the distant roll of wheels announced the coming coach; I went to the door
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and watched its lamps approach rapidly through the gloom.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Is she going by herself?" asked the porter's wife.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And how far is it?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Fifty miles."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What a long way!  I wonder Mrs. Reed is not afraid to trust her so far
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: alone."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: top laden with passengers: the guard and coachman loudly urged haste; my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: trunk was hoisted up; I was taken from Bessie's neck, to which I clung

text: with kisses.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me into the inside.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: right," and on we drove.  Thus was I severed from Bessie and Gateshead;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thus whirled away to unknown, and, as I then deemed, remote and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: mysterious regions.

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me along with Miss Miller.

text: The lady I had left might be about twenty-nine; the one who went with me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: appeared some years younger: the first impressed me by her voice, look,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and air.  Miss Miller was more ordinary; ruddy in complexion, though of a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: careworn countenance; hurried in gait and action, like one who had always
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a multiplicity of tasks on hand: she looked, indeed, what I afterwards
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: found she really was, an under-teacher.  Led by her, I passed from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: compartment to compartment, from passage to passage, of a large and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: irregular building; till, emerging from the total and somewhat dreary
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: silence pervading that portion of the house we had traversed, we came
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: upon the hum of many voices, and presently entered a wide, long room,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with great deal tables, two at each end, on each of which burnt a pair of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: candles, and seated all round on benches, a congregation of girls of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: every age, from nine or ten to twenty.  Seen by the dim light of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dips, their number to me appeared countless, though not in reality
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exceeding eighty; they were uniformly dressed in brown stuff frocks of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quaint fashion, and long holland pinafores.  It was the hour of study;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: they were engaged in conning over their to-morrow's task, and the hum I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had heard was the combined result of their whispered repetitions.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miss Miller signed to me to sit on a bench near the door, then walking up
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to the top of the long room she cried out--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Monitors, collect the lesson-books and put them away!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Four tall girls arose from different tables, and going round, gathered
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the books and removed them.  Miss Miller again gave the word of command--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Monitors, fetch the supper-trays!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The tall girls went out and returned presently, each bearing a tray, with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: portions of something, I knew not what, arranged thereon, and a pitcher
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of water and mug in the middle of each tray.  The portions were handed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: round; those who liked took a draught of the water, the mug being common
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to all.  When it came to my turn, I drank, for I was thirsty, but did not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: touch the food, excitement and fatigue rendering me incapable of eating:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I now saw, however, that it was a thin oaten cake shared into fragments.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The meal over, prayers were read by Miss Miller, and the classes filed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: off, two and two, upstairs.  Overpowered by this time with weariness, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: scarcely noticed what sort of a place the bedroom was, except that, like
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the schoolroom, I saw it was very long.  To-night I was to be Miss
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miller's bed-fellow; she helped me to undress: when laid down I glanced
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: at the long rows of beds, each of which was quickly filled with two
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: occupants; in ten minutes the single light was extinguished, and amidst
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: silence and complete darkness I fell asleep.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The night passed rapidly.  I was too tired even to dream; I only once
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: awoke to hear the wind rave in furious gusts, and the rain fall in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: torrents, and to be sensible that Miss Miller had taken her place by my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: side.  When I again unclosed my eyes, a loud bell was ringing; the girls
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were up and dressing; day had not yet begun to dawn, and a rushlight or
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: two burned in the room.  I too rose reluctantly; it was bitter cold, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I dressed as well as I could for shivering, and washed when there was a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: basin at liberty, which did not occur soon, as there was but one basin to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: six girls, on the stands down the middle of the room.  Again the bell
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: rang: all formed in file, two and two, and in that order descended the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: stairs and entered the cold and dimly lit schoolroom: here prayers were
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: read by Miss Miller; afterwards she called out--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Form classes!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A great tumult succeeded for some minutes, during which Miss Miller
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: repeatedly exclaimed, "Silence!" and "Order!"  When it subsided, I saw
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: them all drawn up in four semicircles, before four chairs, placed at the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: four tables; all held books in their hands, and a great book, like a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Bible, lay on each table, before the vacant seat.  A pause of some
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: seconds succeeded, filled up by the low, vague hum of numbers; Miss
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miller walked from class to class, hushing this indefinite sound.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A distant bell tinkled: immediately three ladies entered the room, each
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: walked to a table and took her seat.  Miss Miller assumed the fourth
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: vacant chair, which was that nearest the door, and around which the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: smallest of the children were assembled: to this inferior class I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: called, and placed at the bottom of it.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Business now began, the day's Collect was repeated, then certain texts of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Scripture were said, and to these succeeded a protracted reading of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: chapters in the Bible, which lasted an hour.  By the time that exercise
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was terminated, day had fully dawned.  The indefatigable bell now sounded
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for the fourth time: the classes were marshalled and marched into another
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: room to breakfast: how glad I was to behold a prospect of getting
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: something to eat!  I was now nearly sick from inanition, having taken so
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: little the day before.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The refectory was a great, low-ceiled, gloomy room; on two long tables
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: smoked basins of something hot, which, however, to my dismay, sent forth
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: an odour far from inviting.  I saw a universal manifestation of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: discontent when the fumes of the repast met the nostrils of those
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: destined to swallow it; from the van of the procession, the tall girls of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the first class, rose the whispered words--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Disgusting!  The porridge is burnt again!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Silence!" ejaculated a voice; not that of Miss Miller, but one of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: upper teachers, a little and dark personage, smartly dressed, but of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: somewhat morose aspect, who installed herself at the top of one table,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: while a more buxom lady presided at the other.  I looked in vain for her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I had first seen the night before; she was not visible: Miss Miller
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: occupied the foot of the table where I sat, and a strange,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: foreign-looking, elderly lady, the French teacher, as I afterwards found,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: took the corresponding seat at the other board.  A long grace was said
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and a hymn sung; then a servant brought in some tea for the teachers, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the meal began.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Ravenous, and now very faint, I devoured a spoonful or two of my portion
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: without thinking of its taste; but the first edge of hunger blunted, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: perceived I had got in hand a nauseous mess; burnt porridge is almost as
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bad as rotten potatoes; famine itself soon sickens over it.  The spoons
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were moved slowly: I saw each girl taste her food and try to swallow it;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: but in most cases the effort was soon relinquished.  Breakfast was over,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and none had breakfasted.  Thanks being returned for what we had not got,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and a second hymn chanted, the refectory was evacuated for the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: schoolroom.  I was one of the last to go out, and in passing the tables,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I saw one teacher take a basin of the porridge and taste it; she looked
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: at the others; all their countenances expressed displeasure, and one of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: them, the stout one, whispered--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Abominable stuff!  How shameful!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A quarter of an hour passed before lessons again began, during which the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: schoolroom was in a glorious tumult; for that space of time it seemed to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be permitted to talk loud and more freely, and they used their privilege.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The whole conversation ran on the breakfast, which one and all abused
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: roundly.  Poor things! it was the sole consolation they had.  Miss Miller
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was now the only teacher in the room: a group of great girls standing
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: about her spoke with serious and sullen gestures.  I heard the name of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Mr. Brocklehurst pronounced by some lips; at which Miss Miller shook her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: head disapprovingly; but she made no great effort to check the general
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wrath; doubtless she shared in it.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A clock in the schoolroom struck nine; Miss Miller left her circle, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: standing in the middle of the room, cried--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Silence!  To your seats!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Discipline prevailed: in five minutes the confused throng was resolved
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: into order, and comparative silence quelled the Babel clamour of tongues.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The upper teachers now punctually resumed their posts: but still, all
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: seemed to wait.  Ranged on benches down the sides of the room, the eighty
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: girls sat motionless and erect; a quaint assemblage they appeared, all
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with plain locks combed from their faces, not a curl visible; in brown
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dresses, made high and surrounded by a narrow tucker about the throat,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with little pockets of holland (shaped something like a Highlander's
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: purse) tied in front of their frocks, and destined to serve the purpose
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of a work-bag: all, too, wearing woollen stockings and country-made
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shoes, fastened with brass buckles.  Above twenty of those clad in this
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: costume were full-grown girls, or rather young women; it suited them ill,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and gave an air of oddity even to the prettiest.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I was still looking at them, and also at intervals examining the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: teachers--none of whom precisely pleased me; for the stout one was a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: little coarse, the dark one not a little fierce, the foreigner harsh and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grotesque, and Miss Miller, poor thing! looked purple, weather-beaten,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and over-worked--when, as my eye wandered from face to face, the whole
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: school rose simultaneously, as if moved by a common spring.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: What was the matter?  I had heard no order given: I was puzzled.  Ere I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had gathered my wits, the classes were again seated: but as all eyes were
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: now turned to one point, mine followed the general direction, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: encountered the personage who had received me last night.  She stood at
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the bottom of the long room, on the hearth; for there was a fire at each
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: end; she surveyed the two rows of girls silently and gravely.  Miss
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miller approaching, seemed to ask her a question, and having received her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: answer, went back to her place, and said aloud--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Monitor of the first class, fetch the globes!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: While the direction was being executed, the lady consulted moved slowly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: up the room.  I suppose I have a considerable organ of veneration, for I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: retain yet the sense of admiring awe with which my eyes traced her steps.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Seen now, in broad daylight, she looked tall, fair, and shapely; brown
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: eyes with a benignant light in their irids, and a fine pencilling of long
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lashes round, relieved the whiteness of her large front; on each of her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: temples her hair, of a very dark brown, was clustered in round curls,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: according to the fashion of those times, when neither smooth bands nor
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: long ringlets were in vogue; her dress, also in the mode of the day, was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of purple cloth, relieved by a sort of Spanish trimming of black velvet;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a gold watch (watches were not so common then as now) shone at her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: girdle.  Let the reader add, to complete the picture, refined features; a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: complexion, if pale, clear; and a stately air and carriage, and he will
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: have, at least, as clearly as words can give it, a correct idea of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exterior of Miss Temple--Maria Temple, as I afterwards saw the name
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: written in a prayer-book intrusted to me to carry to church.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The superintendent of Lowood (for such was this lady) having taken her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: seat before a pair of globes placed on one of the tables, summoned the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: first class round her, and commenced giving a lesson on geography; the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lower classes were called by the teachers: repetitions in history,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grammar, &c., went on for an hour; writing and arithmetic succeeded, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: music lessons were given by Miss Temple to some of the elder girls.  The
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: duration of each lesson was measured by the clock, which at last struck
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: twelve.  The superintendent rose--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I have a word to address to the pupils," said she.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The tumult of cessation from lessons was already breaking forth, but it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sank at her voice.  She went on--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You had this morning a breakfast which you could not eat; you must be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hungry:--I have ordered that a lunch of bread and cheese shall be served
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to all."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The teachers looked at her with a sort of surprise.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "It is to be done on my responsibility," she added, in an explanatory
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: tone to them, and immediately afterwards left the room.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The bread and cheese was presently brought in and distributed, to the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: high delight and refreshment of the whole school.  The order was now
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: given "To the garden!"  Each put on a coarse straw bonnet, with strings
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of coloured calico, and a cloak of grey frieze.  I was similarly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: equipped, and, following the stream, I made my way into the open air.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The garden was a wide inclosure, surrounded with walls so high as to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exclude every glimpse of prospect; a covered verandah ran down one side,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and broad walks bordered a middle space divided into scores of little
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: beds: these beds were assigned as gardens for the pupils to cultivate,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and each bed had an owner.  When full of flowers they would doubtless
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: look pretty; but now, at the latter end of January, all was wintry blight
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and brown decay.  I shuddered as I stood and looked round me: it was an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: inclement day for outdoor exercise; not positively rainy, but darkened by
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a drizzling yellow fog; all under foot was still soaking wet with the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: floods of yesterday.  The stronger among the girls ran about and engaged
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in active games, but sundry pale and thin ones herded together for
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shelter and warmth in the verandah; and amongst these, as the dense mist
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: penetrated to their shivering frames, I heard frequently the sound of a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hollow cough.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: As yet I had spoken to no one, nor did anybody seem to take notice of me;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I stood lonely enough: but to that feeling of isolation I was accustomed;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it did not oppress me much.  I leant against a pillar of the verandah,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: drew my grey mantle close about me, and, trying to forget the cold which
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: nipped me without, and the unsatisfied hunger which gnawed me within,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: delivered myself up to the employment of watching and thinking.  My
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: reflections were too undefined and fragmentary to merit record: I hardly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: yet knew where I was; Gateshead and my past life seemed floated away to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: an immeasurable distance; the present was vague and strange, and of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: future I could form no conjecture.  I looked round the convent-like
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: garden, and then up at the house--a large building, half of which seemed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grey and old, the other half quite new.  The new part, containing the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: schoolroom and dormitory, was lit by mullioned and latticed windows,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: which gave it a church-like aspect; a stone tablet over the door bore
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: this inscription:--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Lowood Institution.--This portion was rebuilt A.D. ---, by Naomi
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Brocklehurst, of Brocklehurst Hall, in this county."  "Let your light so
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Father which is in heaven."--St. Matt. v. 16.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I read these words over and over again: I felt that an explanation
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: belonged to them, and was unable fully to penetrate their import.  I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: still pondering the signification of "Institution," and endeavouring to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: make out a connection between the first words and the verse of Scripture,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: when the sound of a cough close behind me made me turn my head.  I saw a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: girl sitting on a stone bench near; she was bent over a book, on the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: perusal of which she seemed intent: from where I stood I could see the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: title--it was "Rasselas;" a name that struck me as strange, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: consequently attractive.  In turning a leaf she happened to look up, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I said to her directly--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Is your book interesting?"  I had already formed the intention of asking
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: her to lend it to me some day.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I like it," she answered, after a pause of a second or two, during which
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she examined me.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What is it about?" I continued.  I hardly know where I found the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hardihood thus to open a conversation with a stranger; the step was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: contrary to my nature and habits: but I think her occupation touched a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: chord of sympathy somewhere; for I too liked reading, though of a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: frivolous and childish kind; I could not digest or comprehend the serious
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: or substantial.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You may look at it," replied the girl, offering me the book.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I did so; a brief examination convinced me that the contents were less
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: taking than the title: "Rasselas" looked dull to my trifling taste; I saw
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: nothing about fairies, nothing about genii; no bright variety seemed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spread over the closely-printed pages.  I returned it to her; she
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: received it quietly, and without saying anything she was about to relapse
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: into her former studious mood: again I ventured to disturb her--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Can you tell me what the writing on that stone over the door means?  What
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: is Lowood Institution?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "This house where you are come to live."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And why do they call it Institution?  Is it in any way different from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: other schools?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "It is partly a charity-school: you and I, and all the rest of us, are
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: charity-children.  I suppose you are an orphan: are not either your
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: father or your mother dead?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Both died before I can remember."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Well, all the girls here have lost either one or both parents, and this
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: is called an institution for educating orphans."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Do we pay no money?  Do they keep us for nothing?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "We pay, or our friends pay, fifteen pounds a year for each."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Then why do they call us charity-children?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Because fifteen pounds is not enough for board and teaching, and the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: deficiency is supplied by subscription."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Who subscribes?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Different benevolent-minded ladies and gentlemen in this neighbourhood
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and in London."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Who was Naomi Brocklehurst?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "The lady who built the new part of this house as that tablet records,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and whose son overlooks and directs everything here."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Why?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Because he is treasurer and manager of the establishment."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Then this house does not belong to that tall lady who wears a watch, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: who said we were to have some bread and cheese?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "To Miss Temple?  Oh, no!  I wish it did: she has to answer to Mr.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Brocklehurst for all she does.  Mr. Brocklehurst buys all our food and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: all our clothes."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Does he live here?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No--two miles off, at a large hall."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Is he a good man?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "He is a clergyman, and is said to do a great deal of good."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Did you say that tall lady was called Miss Temple?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And what are the other teachers called?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "The one with red cheeks is called Miss Smith; she attends to the work,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and cuts out--for we make our own clothes, our frocks, and pelisses, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: everything; the little one with black hair is Miss Scatcherd; she teaches
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: history and grammar, and hears the second class repetitions; and the one
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: who wears a shawl, and has a pocket-handkerchief tied to her side with a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: yellow ribband, is Madame Pierrot: she comes from Lisle, in France, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: teaches French."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Do you like the teachers?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Well enough."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Do you like the little black one, and the Madame ---?--I cannot
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pronounce her name as you do."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Miss Scatcherd is hasty--you must take care not to offend her; Madame
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Pierrot is not a bad sort of person."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "But Miss Temple is the best--isn't she?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Miss Temple is very good and very clever; she is above the rest, because
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she knows far more than they do."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Have you been long here?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Two years."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Are you an orphan?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "My mother is dead."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Are you happy here?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You ask rather too many questions.  I have given you answers enough for
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the present: now I want to read."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: But at that moment the summons sounded for dinner; all re-entered the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: house.  The odour which now filled the refectory was scarcely more
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: appetising than that which had regaled our nostrils at breakfast: the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dinner was served in two huge tin-plated vessels, whence rose a strong
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: steam redolent of rancid fat.  I found the mess to consist of indifferent
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: potatoes and strange shreds of rusty meat, mixed and cooked together.  Of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: this preparation a tolerably abundant plateful was apportioned to each
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pupil.  I ate what I could, and wondered within myself whether every
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: day's fare would be like this.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: After dinner, we immediately adjourned to the schoolroom: lessons
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: recommenced, and were continued till five o'clock.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The only marked event of the afternoon was, that I saw the girl with whom
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I had conversed in the verandah dismissed in disgrace by Miss Scatcherd
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: from a history class, and sent to stand in the middle of the large
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: schoolroom.  The punishment seemed to me in a high degree ignominious,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: especially for so great a girl--she looked thirteen or upwards.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: expected she would show signs of great distress and shame; but to my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: surprise she neither wept nor blushed: composed, though grave, she stood,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the central mark of all eyes.  "How can she bear it so quietly--so
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: firmly?" I asked of myself.  "Were I in her place, it seems to me I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: should wish the earth to open and swallow me up.  She looks as if she
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were thinking of something beyond her punishment--beyond her situation:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of something not round her nor before her.  I have heard of day-dreams--is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she in a day-dream now?  Her eyes are fixed on the floor, but I am sure
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: they do not see it--her sight seems turned in, gone down into her heart:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she is looking at what she can remember, I believe; not at what is really
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: present.  I wonder what sort of a girl she is--whether good or naughty."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Soon after five p.m. we had another meal, consisting of a small mug of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: coffee, and half-a-slice of brown bread.  I devoured my bread and drank
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my coffee with relish; but I should have been glad of as much more--I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: still hungry.  Half-an-hour's recreation succeeded, then study; then the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: glass of water and the piece of oat-cake, prayers, and bed.  Such was my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: first day at Lowood.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The next day commenced as before, getting up and dressing by rushlight;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: but this morning we were obliged to dispense with the ceremony of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: washing; the water in the pitchers was frozen.  A change had taken place
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in the weather the preceding evening, and a keen north-east wind,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: whistling through the crevices of our bedroom windows all night long, had
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: made us shiver in our beds, and turned the contents of the ewers to ice.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Before the long hour and a half of prayers and Bible-reading was over, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: felt ready to perish with cold.  Breakfast-time came at last, and this
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: morning the porridge was not burnt; the quality was eatable, the quantity
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: small.  How small my portion seemed!  I wished it had been doubled.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: In the course of the day I was enrolled a member of the fourth class, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: regular tasks and occupations were assigned me: hitherto, I had only been
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a spectator of the proceedings at Lowood; I was now to become an actor
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: therein.  At first, being little accustomed to learn by heart, the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lessons appeared to me both long and difficult; the frequent change from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: task to task, too, bewildered me; and I was glad when, about three
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: o'clock in the afternoon, Miss Smith put into my hands a border of muslin
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: two yards long, together with needle, thimble, &c., and sent me to sit in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a quiet corner of the schoolroom, with directions to hem the same.  At
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that hour most of the others were sewing likewise; but one class still
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: stood round Miss Scatcherd's chair reading, and as all was quiet, the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: subject of their lessons could be heard, together with the manner in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: which each girl acquitted herself, and the animadversions or
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: commendations of Miss Scatcherd on the performance.  It was English
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: history: among the readers I observed my acquaintance of the verandah: at
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the commencement of the lesson, her place had been at the top of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: class, but for some error of pronunciation, or some inattention to stops,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she was suddenly sent to the very bottom.  Even in that obscure position,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was continually addressing to her such phrases as the following:--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: their surnames, as boys are elsewhere), "Burns, you are standing on the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: side of your shoe; turn your toes out immediately."  "Burns, you poke
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: your chin most unpleasantly; draw it in."  "Burns, I insist on your
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: holding your head up; I will not have you before me in that attitude,"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I., and there were sundry questions about tonnage and poundage and ship-
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: money, which most of them appeared unable to answer; still, every little
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to have retained the substance of the whole lesson, and she was ready
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with answers on every point.  I kept expecting that Miss Scatcherd would
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: morning!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: as the water was frozen?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of thread: while she was winding it, she talked to me from time to time,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: stitch, knit, &c.; till she dismissed me, I could not pursue my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Hardened girl!" exclaimed Miss Scatcherd; "nothing can correct you of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: your slatternly habits: carry the rod away."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: day at Lowood: the bit of bread, the draught of coffee swallowed at five
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: o'clock had revived vitality, if it had not satisfied hunger: the long
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: On the evening of the day on which I had seen Miss Scatcherd flog her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pupil, Burns, I wandered as usual among the forms and tables and laughing
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to the window, I could distinguish from the gleeful tumult within, the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Probably, if I had lately left a good home and kind parents, this would
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: more wildly, the gloom to deepen to darkness, and the confusion to rise
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to clamour.

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: book, which she read by the dim glare of the embers.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: floor.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What is your name besides Burns?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Helen."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Do you come a long way from here?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I come from a place farther north, quite on the borders of Scotland."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Will you ever go back?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I hope so; but nobody can be sure of the future."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You must wish to leave Lowood?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No! why should I?  I was sent to Lowood to get an education; and it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: would be of no use going away until I have attained that object."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "But that teacher, Miss Scatcherd, is so cruel to you?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Cruel?  Not at all!  She is severe: she dislikes my faults."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And if I were in your place I should dislike her; I should resist her.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: If she struck me with that rod, I should get it from her hand; I should

text: break it under her nose."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Probably you would do nothing of the sort: but if you did, Mr.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to your relations.  It is far better to endure patiently a smart which
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Heathens and savage tribes hold that doctrine, but Christians and

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "How?  I don't understand."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "It is not violence that best overcomes hate--nor vengeance that most
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What then?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Read the New Testament, and observe what Christ says, and how He acts;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: make His word your rule, and His conduct your example."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What does He say?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Love your enemies; bless them that curse you; do good to them that hate
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: you and despitefully use you."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Then I should love Mrs. Reed, which I cannot do; I should bless her son
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: John, which is impossible."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: In her turn, Helen Burns asked me to explain, and I proceeded forthwith
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to pour out, in my own way, the tale of my sufferings and resentments.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Bitter and truculent when excited, I spoke as I felt, without reserve or
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: softening.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Helen heard me patiently to the end: I expected she would then make a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remark, but she said nothing.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Well," I asked impatiently, "is not Mrs. Reed a hard-hearted, bad
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: woman?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "She has been unkind to you, no doubt; because you see, she dislikes your
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: cast of character, as Miss Scatcherd does mine; but how minutely you
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remember all she has done and said to you!  What a singularly deep
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: impression her injustice seems to have made on your heart!  No ill-usage
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: so brands its record on my feelings.  Would you not be happier if you
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: tried to forget her severity, together with the passionate emotions it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: excited?  Life appears to me too short to be spent in nursing animosity
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: or registering wrongs.  We are, and must be, one and all, burdened with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: faults in this world: but the time will soon come when, I trust, we shall
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: put them off in putting off our corruptible bodies; when debasement and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sin will fall from us with this cumbrous frame of flesh, and only the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spark of the spirit will remain,--the impalpable principle of light and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thought, pure as when it left the Creator to inspire the creature: whence
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it came it will return; perhaps again to be communicated to some being
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: higher than man--perhaps to pass through gradations of glory, from the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pale human soul to brighten to the seraph!  Surely it will never, on the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: contrary, be suffered to degenerate from man to fiend?  No; I cannot
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: believe that: I hold another creed: which no one ever taught me, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: which I seldom mention; but in which I delight, and to which I cling: for
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it extends hope to all: it makes Eternity a rest--a mighty home, not a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: terror and an abyss.  Besides, with this creed, I can so clearly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: distinguish between the criminal and his crime; I can so sincerely
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: forgive the first while I abhor the last: with this creed revenge never
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: worries my heart, degradation never too deeply disgusts me, injustice
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: never crushes me too low: I live in calm, looking to the end."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Helen's head, always drooping, sank a little lower as she finished this
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sentence.  I saw by her look she wished no longer to talk to me, but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: rather to converse with her own thoughts.  She was not allowed much time
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for meditation: a monitor, a great rough girl, presently came up,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exclaiming in a strong Cumberland accent--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Helen Burns, if you don't go and put your drawer in order, and fold up
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: your work this minute, I'll tell Miss Scatcherd to come and look at it!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Helen sighed as her reverie fled, and getting up, obeyed the monitor
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: without reply as without delay.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: My first quarter at Lowood seemed an age; and not the golden age either;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it comprised an irksome struggle with difficulties in habituating myself
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to new rules and unwonted tasks.  The fear of failure in these points
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: harassed me worse than the physical hardships of my lot; though these
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were no trifles.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: During January, February, and part of March, the deep snows, and, after
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: their melting, the almost impassable roads, prevented our stirring beyond
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the garden walls, except to go to church; but within these limits we had
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to pass an hour every day in the open air.  Our clothing was insufficient
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to protect us from the severe cold: we had no boots, the snow got into
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: our shoes and melted there: our ungloved hands became numbed and covered
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with chilblains, as were our feet: I remember well the distracting
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: irritation I endured from this cause every evening, when my feet
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: inflamed; and the torture of thrusting the swelled, raw, and stiff toes
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: into my shoes in the morning.  Then the scanty supply of food was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: distressing: with the keen appetites of growing children, we had scarcely
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sufficient to keep alive a delicate invalid.  From this deficiency of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: nourishment resulted an abuse, which pressed hardly on the younger
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pupils: whenever the famished great girls had an opportunity, they would
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: coax or menace the little ones out of their portion.  Many a time I have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shared between two claimants the precious morsel of brown bread
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: distributed at tea-time; and after relinquishing to a third half the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: contents of my mug of coffee, I have swallowed the remainder with an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: accompaniment of secret tears, forced from me by the exigency of hunger.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Sundays were dreary days in that wintry season.  We had to walk two miles
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to Brocklebridge Church, where our patron officiated.  We set out cold,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: we arrived at church colder: during the morning service we became almost
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: paralysed.  It was too far to return to dinner, and an allowance of cold
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: meat and bread, in the same penurious proportion observed in our ordinary
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: meals, was served round between the services.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: At the close of the afternoon service we returned by an exposed and hilly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: road, where the bitter winter wind, blowing over a range of snowy summits
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to the north, almost flayed the skin from our faces.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I can remember Miss Temple walking lightly and rapidly along our drooping
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: line, her plaid cloak, which the frosty wind fluttered, gathered close
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: about her, and encouraging us, by precept and example, to keep up our
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spirits, and march forward, as she said, "like stalwart soldiers."  The
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: other teachers, poor things, were generally themselves too much dejected
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to attempt the task of cheering others.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: How we longed for the light and heat of a blazing fire when we got back!
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: But, to the little ones at least, this was denied: each hearth in the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: schoolroom was immediately surrounded by a double row of great girls, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: behind them the younger children crouched in groups, wrapping their
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: starved arms in their pinafores.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A little solace came at tea-time, in the shape of a double ration of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bread--a whole, instead of a half, slice--with the delicious addition of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a thin scrape of butter: it was the hebdomadal treat to which we all
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: looked forward from Sabbath to Sabbath.  I generally contrived to reserve
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a moiety of this bounteous repast for myself; but the remainder I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: invariably obliged to part with.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The Sunday evening was spent in repeating, by heart, the Church
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Catechism, and the fifth, sixth, and seventh chapters of St. Matthew; and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in listening to a long sermon, read by Miss Miller, whose irrepressible
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: yawns attested her weariness.  A frequent interlude of these performances
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was the enactment of the part of Eutychus by some half-dozen of little
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: girls, who, overpowered with sleep, would fall down, if not out of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: third loft, yet off the fourth form, and be taken up half dead.  The
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remedy was, to thrust them forward into the centre of the schoolroom, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: oblige them to stand there till the sermon was finished.  Sometimes their
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feet failed them, and they sank together in a heap; they were then
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: propped up with the monitors' high stools.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I have not yet alluded to the visits of Mr. Brocklehurst; and indeed that
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: gentleman was from home during the greater part of the first month after
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my arrival; perhaps prolonging his stay with his friend the archdeacon:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: his absence was a relief to me.  I need not say that I had my own reasons
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for dreading his coming: but come he did at last.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: One afternoon (I had then been three weeks at Lowood), as I was sitting
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with a slate in my hand, puzzling over a sum in long division, my eyes,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fulfilment of this promise,--I had been looking out daily for the "Coming
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Man," whose information respecting my past life and conversation was to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: brand me as a bad child for ever: now there he was.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: He stood at Miss Temple's side; he was speaking low in her ear: I did not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: doubt he was making disclosures of my villainy; and I watched her eye
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with painful anxiety, expecting every moment to see its dark orb turn on
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER IX
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: But the privations, or rather the hardships, of Lowood lessened.  Spring
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: drew on: she was indeed already come; the frosts of winter had ceased;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: its snows were melted, its cutting winds ameliorated.  My wretched feet,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: flayed and swollen to lameness by the sharp air of January, began to heal
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and subside under the gentler breathings of April; the nights and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography
