text: "He says she'll not be here long."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: This phrase, uttered in my hearing yesterday, would have only conveyed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the notion that she was about to be removed to Northumberland, to her own
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: home.  I should not have suspected that it meant she was dying; but I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: knew instantly now!  It opened clear on my comprehension that Helen Burns
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was numbering her last days in this world, and that she was going to be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: taken to the region of spirits, if such region there were.  I experienced
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a shock of horror, then a strong thrill of grief, then a desire--a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: necessity to see her; and I asked in what room she lay.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "She is in Miss Temple's room," said the nurse.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "May I go up and speak to her?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Oh no, child!  It is not likely; and now it is time for you to come in;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: you'll catch the fever if you stop out when the dew is falling."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The nurse closed the front door; I went in by the side entrance which led
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to the schoolroom: I was just in time; it was nine o'clock, and Miss
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miller was calling the pupils to go to bed.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: It might be two hours later, probably near eleven, when I--not having
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: been able to fall asleep, and deeming, from the perfect silence of the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dormitory, that my companions were all wrapt in profound repose--rose
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: softly, put on my frock over my night-dress, and, without shoes, crept
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: from the apartment, and set off in quest of Miss Temple's room.  It was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quite at the other end of the house; but I knew my way; and the light of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the unclouded summer moon, entering here and there at passage windows,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: enabled me to find it without difficulty.  An odour of camphor and burnt
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: vinegar warned me when I came near the fever room: and I passed its door
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quickly, fearful lest the nurse who sat up all night should hear me.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dreaded being discovered and sent back; for I _must_ see Helen,--I must
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: embrace her before she died,--I must give her one last kiss, exchange
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with her one last word.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Having descended a staircase, traversed a portion of the house below, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: succeeded in opening and shutting, without noise, two doors, I reached
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: another flight of steps; these I mounted, and then just opposite to me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was Miss Temple's room.  A light shone through the keyhole and from under
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the door; a profound stillness pervaded the vicinity.  Coming near, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: found the door slightly ajar; probably to admit some fresh air into the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: close abode of sickness.  Indisposed to hesitate, and full of impatient
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: impulses--soul and senses quivering with keen throes--I put it back and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: looked in.  My eye sought Helen, and feared to find death.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Close by Miss Temple's bed, and half covered with its white curtains,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: there stood a little crib.  I saw the outline of a form under the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: clothes, but the face was hid by the hangings: the nurse I had spoken to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in the garden sat in an easy-chair asleep; an unsnuffed candle burnt
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dimly on the table.  Miss Temple was not to be seen: I knew afterwards
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that she had been called to a delirious patient in the fever-room.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: advanced; then paused by the crib side: my hand was on the curtain, but I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: preferred speaking before I withdrew it.  I still recoiled at the dread
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of seeing a corpse.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Helen!" I whispered softly, "are you awake?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: She stirred herself, put back the curtain, and I saw her face, pale,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wasted, but quite composed: she looked so little changed that my fear was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: instantly dissipated.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Can it be you, Jane?" she asked, in her own gentle voice.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Oh!" I thought, "she is not going to die; they are mistaken: she could
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: not speak and look so calmly if she were."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I got on to her crib and kissed her: her forehead was cold, and her cheek
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: both cold and thin, and so were her hand and wrist; but she smiled as of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: old.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Why are you come here, Jane?  It is past eleven o'clock: I heard it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: strike some minutes since."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I came to see you, Helen: I heard you were very ill, and I could not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sleep till I had spoken to you."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You came to bid me good-bye, then: you are just in time probably."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Are you going somewhere, Helen?  Are you going home?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes; to my long home--my last home."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No, no, Helen!"  I stopped, distressed.  While I tried to devour my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: tears, a fit of coughing seized Helen; it did not, however, wake the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: nurse; when it was over, she lay some minutes exhausted; then she
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: whispered--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Jane, your little feet are bare; lie down and cover yourself with my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quilt."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I did so: she put her arm over me, and I nestled close to her.  After a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: long silence, she resumed, still whispering--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I am very happy, Jane; and when you hear that I am dead, you must be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sure and not grieve: there is nothing to grieve about.  We all must die
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: one day, and the illness which is removing me is not painful; it is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: gentle and gradual: my mind is at rest.  I leave no one to regret me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: much: I have only a father; and he is lately married, and will not miss
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me.  By dying young, I shall escape great sufferings.  I had not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: qualities or talents to make my way very well in the world: I should have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: been continually at fault."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "But where are you going to, Helen?  Can you see?  Do you know?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I believe; I have faith: I am going to God."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Where is God?  What is God?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "My Maker and yours, who will never destroy what He created.  I rely
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: implicitly on His power, and confide wholly in His goodness: I count the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hours till that eventful one arrives which shall restore me to Him,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: reveal Him to me."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You are sure, then, Helen, that there is such a place as heaven, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that our souls can get to it when we die?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I am sure there is a future state; I believe God is good; I can resign
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my immortal part to Him without any misgiving.  God is my father; God is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my friend: I love Him; I believe He loves me."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And shall I see you again, Helen, when I die?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You will come to the same region of happiness: be received by the same
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: mighty, universal Parent, no doubt, dear Jane."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Again I questioned, but this time only in thought.  "Where is that
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: region?  Does it exist?"  And I clasped my arms closer round Helen; she
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: seemed dearer to me than ever; I felt as if I could not let her go; I lay
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with my face hidden on her neck.  Presently she said, in the sweetest
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: tone--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "How comfortable I am!  That last fit of coughing has tired me a little;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I feel as if I could sleep: but don't leave me, Jane; I like to have you
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: near me."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I'll stay with you, _dear_ Helen: no one shall take me away."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Are you warm, darling?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Good-night, Jane."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Good-night, Helen."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: She kissed me, and I her, and we both soon slumbered.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: When I awoke it was day: an unusual movement roused me; I looked up; I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was in somebody's arms; the nurse held me; she was carrying me through
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the passage back to the dormitory.  I was not reprimanded for leaving my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bed; people had something else to think about; no explanation was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: afforded then to my many questions; but a day or two afterwards I learned
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that Miss Temple, on returning to her own room at dawn, had found me laid
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in the little crib; my face against Helen Burns's shoulder, my arms round
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: her neck.  I was asleep, and Helen was--dead.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Her grave is in Brocklebridge churchyard: for fifteen years after her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: death it was only covered by a grassy mound; but now a grey marble tablet
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: marks the spot, inscribed with her name, and the word "Resurgam."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER X
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Hitherto I have recorded in detail the events of my insignificant
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: existence: to the first ten years of my life I have given almost as many
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: chapters.  But this is not to be a regular autobiography.  I am only
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bound to invoke Memory where I know her responses will possess some
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: degree of interest; therefore I now pass a space of eight years almost in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: silence: a few lines only are necessary to keep up the links of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: connection.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: When the typhus fever had fulfilled its mission of devastation at Lowood,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it gradually disappeared from thence; but not till its virulence and the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: number of its victims had drawn public attention on the school.  Inquiry
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was made into the origin of the scourge, and by degrees various facts
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: came out which excited public indignation in a high degree.  The
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: unhealthy nature of the site; the quantity and quality of the children's
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: food; the brackish, fetid water used in its preparation; the pupils'
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wretched clothing and accommodations--all these things were discovered,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and the discovery produced a result mortifying to Mr. Brocklehurst, but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: beneficial to the institution.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Several wealthy and benevolent individuals in the county subscribed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: largely for the erection of a more convenient building in a better
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: situation; new regulations were made; improvements in diet and clothing
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: introduced; the funds of the school were intrusted to the management of a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: committee.  Mr. Brocklehurst, who, from his wealth and family
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: connections, could not be overlooked, still retained the post of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: treasurer; but he was aided in the discharge of his duties by gentlemen
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of rather more enlarged and sympathising minds: his office of inspector,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: too, was shared by those who knew how to combine reason with strictness,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: comfort with economy, compassion with uprightness.  The school, thus
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: improved, became in time a truly useful and noble institution.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remained an inmate of its walls, after its regeneration, for eight years:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: six as pupil, and two as teacher; and in both capacities I bear my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: testimony to its value and importance.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: During these eight years my life was uniform: but not unhappy, because it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was not inactive.  I had the means of an excellent education placed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: within my reach; a fondness for some of my studies, and a desire to excel
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in all, together with a great delight in pleasing my teachers, especially
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: such as I loved, urged me on: I availed myself fully of the advantages
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: offered me.  In time I rose to be the first girl of the first class; then
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I was invested with the office of teacher; which I discharged with zeal
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for two years: but at the end of that time I altered.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miss Temple, through all changes, had thus far continued superintendent
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of the seminary: to her instruction I owed the best part of my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: acquirements; her friendship and society had been my continual solace;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she had stood me in the stead of mother, governess, and, latterly,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: companion.  At this period she married, removed with her husband (a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: clergyman, an excellent man, almost worthy of such a wife) to a distant
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: county, and consequently was lost to me.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: From the day she left I was no longer the same: with her was gone every
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: settled feeling, every association that had made Lowood in some degree a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: home to me.  I had imbibed from her something of her nature and much of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: her habits: more harmonious thoughts: what seemed better regulated
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feelings had become the inmates of my mind.  I had given in allegiance to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: duty and order; I was quiet; I believed I was content: to the eyes of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: others, usually even to my own, I appeared a disciplined and subdued
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: character.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: But destiny, in the shape of the Rev. Mr. Nasmyth, came between me and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miss Temple: I saw her in her travelling dress step into a post-chaise,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shortly after the marriage ceremony; I watched the chaise mount the hill
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and disappear beyond its brow; and then retired to my own room, and there
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spent in solitude the greatest part of the half-holiday granted in honour
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of the occasion.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I walked about the chamber most of the time.  I imagined myself only to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be regretting my loss, and thinking how to repair it; but when my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: reflections were concluded, and I looked up and found that the afternoon
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was gone, and evening far advanced, another discovery dawned on me,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: namely, that in the interval I had undergone a transforming process; that
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my mind had put off all it had borrowed of Miss Temple--or rather that
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she had taken with her the serene atmosphere I had been breathing in her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: vicinity--and that now I was left in my natural element, and beginning to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feel the stirring of old emotions.  It did not seem as if a prop were
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: withdrawn, but rather as if a motive were gone: it was not the power to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be tranquil which had failed me, but the reason for tranquillity was no
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: more.  My world had for some years been in Lowood: my experience had been
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of its rules and systems; now I remembered that the real world was wide,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and that a varied field of hopes and fears, of sensations and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: excitements, awaited those who had courage to go forth into its expanse,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to seek real knowledge of life amidst its perils.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I went to my window, opened it, and looked out.  There were the two wings
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of the building; there was the garden; there were the skirts of Lowood;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: there was the hilly horizon.  My eye passed all other objects to rest on
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: those most remote, the blue peaks; it was those I longed to surmount; all
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: within their boundary of rock and heath seemed prison-ground, exile
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: limits.  I traced the white road winding round the base of one mountain,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and vanishing in a gorge between two; how I longed to follow it farther!
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I recalled the time when I had travelled that very road in a coach; I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remembered descending that hill at twilight; an age seemed to have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: elapsed since the day which brought me first to Lowood, and I had never
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quitted it since.  My vacations had all been spent at school: Mrs. Reed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had never sent for me to Gateshead; neither she nor any of her family had
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ever been to visit me.  I had had no communication by letter or message
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with the outer world: school-rules, school-duties, school-habits and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: notions, and voices, and faces, and phrases, and costumes, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: preferences, and antipathies--such was what I knew of existence.  And now
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I felt that it was not enough; I tired of the routine of eight years in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: one afternoon.  I desired liberty; for liberty I gasped; for liberty I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: uttered a prayer; it seemed scattered on the wind then faintly blowing.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: abandoned it and framed a humbler supplication; for change, stimulus:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that petition, too, seemed swept off into vague space: "Then," I cried,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: half desperate, "grant me at least a new servitude!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Here a bell, ringing the hour of supper, called me downstairs.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I was not free to resume the interrupted chain of my reflections till
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bedtime: even then a teacher who occupied the same room with me kept me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: from the subject to which I longed to recur, by a prolonged effusion of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: small talk.  How I wished sleep would silence her.  It seemed as if,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could I but go back to the idea which had last entered my mind as I stood
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: at the window, some inventive suggestion would rise for my relief.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Miss Gryce snored at last; she was a heavy Welshwoman, and till now her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: habitual nasal strains had never been regarded by me in any other light
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: than as a nuisance; to-night I hailed the first deep notes with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: satisfaction; I was debarrassed of interruption; my half-effaced thought
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: instantly revived.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "A new servitude!  There is something in that," I soliloquised (mentally,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be it understood; I did not talk aloud), "I know there is, because it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: does not sound too sweet; it is not like such words as Liberty,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Excitement, Enjoyment: delightful sounds truly; but no more than sounds
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for me; and so hollow and fleeting that it is mere waste of time to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: listen to them.  But Servitude!  That must be matter of fact.  Any one
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: may serve: I have served here eight years; now all I want is to serve
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: elsewhere.  Can I not get so much of my own will?  Is not the thing
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feasible?  Yes--yes--the end is not so difficult; if I had only a brain
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: active enough to ferret out the means of attaining it."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I sat up in bed by way of arousing this said brain: it was a chilly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: night; I covered my shoulders with a shawl, and then I proceeded _to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: think_ again with all my might.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What do I want?  A new place, in a new house, amongst new faces, under
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: new circumstances: I want this because it is of no use wanting anything
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: better.  How do people do to get a new place?  They apply to friends, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: suppose: I have no friends.  There are many others who have no friends,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: who must look about for themselves and be their own helpers; and what is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: their resource?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I could not tell: nothing answered me; I then ordered my brain to find a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: response, and quickly.  It worked and worked faster: I felt the pulses
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: throb in my head and temples; but for nearly an hour it worked in chaos;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and no result came of its efforts.  Feverish with vain labour, I got up
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and took a turn in the room; undrew the curtain, noted a star or two,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shivered with cold, and again crept to bed.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A kind fairy, in my absence, had surely dropped the required suggestion
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: on my pillow; for as I lay down, it came quietly and naturally to my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: mind.--"Those who want situations advertise; you must advertise in the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: _---shire Herald_."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "How?  I know nothing about advertising."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Replies rose smooth and prompt now:--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You must enclose the advertisement and the money to pay for it under a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: cover directed to the editor of the _Herald_; you must put it, the first

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: continued the widow; "not altogether unobjectionable in some points, but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she does well enough.  By-the-bye, how have you got on with your new
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pupil this morning?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The conversation, thus turned on Adele, continued till we reached the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: light and cheerful region below.  Adele came running to meet us in the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hall, exclaiming--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Mesdames, vous etes servies!" adding, "J'ai bien faim, moi!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER XII
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The promise of a smooth career, which my first calm introduction to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Thornfield Hall seemed to pledge, was not belied on a longer acquaintance
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with the place and its inmates.  Mrs. Fairfax turned out to be what she
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: appeared, a placid-tempered, kind-natured woman, of competent education
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and average intelligence.  My pupil was a lively child, who had been
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spoilt and indulged, and therefore was sometimes wayward; but as she was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: committed entirely to my care, and no injudicious interference from any
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quarter ever thwarted my plans for her improvement, she soon forgot her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: little freaks, and became obedient and teachable.  She had no great
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: talents, no marked traits of character, no peculiar development of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feeling or taste which raised her one inch above the ordinary level of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: childhood; but neither had she any deficiency or vice which sunk her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: below it.  She made reasonable progress, entertained for me a vivacious,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: though perhaps not very profound, affection; and by her simplicity, gay
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: prattle, and efforts to please, inspired me, in return, with a degree of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: attachment sufficient to make us both content in each other's society.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: This, _par parenthese_, will be thought cool language by persons who
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: entertain solemn doctrines about the angelic nature of children, and the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: duty of those charged with their education to conceive for them an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: idolatrous devotion: but I am not writing to flatter parental egotism, to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: echo cant, or prop up humbug; I am merely telling the truth.  I felt a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: conscientious solicitude for Adele's welfare and progress, and a quiet
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: liking for her little self: just as I cherished towards Mrs. Fairfax a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thankfulness for her kindness, and a pleasure in her society
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: proportionate to the tranquil regard she had for me, and the moderation
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of her mind and character.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Anybody may blame me who likes, when I add further, that, now and then,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: when I took a walk by myself in the grounds; when I went down to the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: gates and looked through them along the road; or when, while Adele played
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with her nurse, and Mrs. Fairfax made jellies in the storeroom, I climbed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the three staircases, raised the trap-door of the attic, and having
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: reached the leads, looked out afar over sequestered field and hill, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: along dim sky-line--that then I longed for a power of vision which might
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: overpass that limit; which might reach the busy world, towns, regions
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: full of life I had heard of but never seen--that then I desired more of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: practical experience than I possessed; more of intercourse with my kind,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of acquaintance with variety of character, than was here within my reach.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I valued what was good in Mrs. Fairfax, and what was good in Adele; but I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: believed in the existence of other and more vivid kinds of goodness, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: what I believed in I wished to behold.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Who blames me?  Many, no doubt; and I shall be called discontented.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could not help it: the restlessness was in my nature; it agitated me to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pain sometimes.  Then my sole relief was to walk along the corridor of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the third storey, backwards and forwards, safe in the silence and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: solitude of the spot, and allow my mind's eye to dwell on whatever bright
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: visions rose before it--and, certainly, they were many and glowing; to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: let my heart be heaved by the exultant movement, which, while it swelled
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it in trouble, expanded it with life; and, best of all, to open my inward
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ear to a tale that was never ended--a tale my imagination created, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: narrated continuously; quickened with all of incident, life, fire,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feeling, that I desired and had not in my actual existence.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: It is in vain to say human beings ought to be satisfied with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: tranquillity: they must have action; and they will make it if they cannot
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: find it.  Millions are condemned to a stiller doom than mine, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: millions are in silent revolt against their lot.  Nobody knows how many
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: rebellions besides political rebellions ferment in the masses of life
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: which people earth.  Women are supposed to be very calm generally: but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: women feel just as men feel; they need exercise for their faculties, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a field for their efforts, as much as their brothers do; they suffer from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: too rigid a restraint, too absolute a stagnation, precisely as men would
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: suffer; and it is narrow-minded in their more privileged fellow-creatures
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to say that they ought to confine themselves to making puddings and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: knitting stockings, to playing on the piano and embroidering bags.  It is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thoughtless to condemn them, or laugh at them, if they seek to do more or
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: learn more than custom has pronounced necessary for their sex.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: When thus alone, I not unfrequently heard Grace Poole's laugh: the same
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: peal, the same low, slow ha! ha! which, when first heard, had thrilled
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me: I heard, too, her eccentric murmurs; stranger than her laugh.  There
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were days when she was quite silent; but there were others when I could
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: not account for the sounds she made.  Sometimes I saw her: she would come
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: out of her room with a basin, or a plate, or a tray in her hand, go down
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to the kitchen and shortly return, generally (oh, romantic reader,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: forgive me for telling the plain truth!) bearing a pot of porter.  Her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: appearance always acted as a damper to the curiosity raised by her oral
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: oddities: hard-featured and staid, she had no point to which interest
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could attach.  I made some attempts to draw her into conversation, but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she seemed a person of few words: a monosyllabic reply usually cut short
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: every effort of that sort.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The other members of the household, viz., John and his wife, Leah the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: housemaid, and Sophie the French nurse, were decent people; but in no
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: respect remarkable; with Sophie I used to talk French, and sometimes I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: asked her questions about her native country; but she was not of a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: descriptive or narrative turn, and generally gave such vapid and confused
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: answers as were calculated rather to check than encourage inquiry.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: October, November, December passed away.  One afternoon in January, Mrs.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Fairfax had begged a holiday for Adele, because she had a cold; and, as
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Adele seconded the request with an ardour that reminded me how precious
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: occasional holidays had been to me in my own childhood, I accorded it,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: deeming that I did well in showing pliability on the point.  It was a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fine, calm day, though very cold; I was tired of sitting still in the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: library through a whole long morning: Mrs. Fairfax had just written a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: letter which was waiting to be posted, so I put on my bonnet and cloak
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and volunteered to carry it to Hay; the distance, two miles, would be a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pleasant winter afternoon walk.  Having seen Adele comfortably seated in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: her little chair by Mrs. Fairfax's parlour fireside, and given her her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: best wax doll (which I usually kept enveloped in silver paper in a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: drawer) to play with, and a story-book for change of amusement; and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: having replied to her "Revenez bientot, ma bonne amie, ma chere Mdlle.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Jeannette," with a kiss I set out.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The ground was hard, the air was still, my road was lonely; I walked fast
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: till I got warm, and then I walked slowly to enjoy and analyse the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: species of pleasure brooding for me in the hour and situation.  It was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: three o'clock; the church bell tolled as I passed under the belfry: the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: charm of the hour lay in its approaching dimness, in the low-gliding and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pale-beaming sun.  I was a mile from Thornfield, in a lane noted for wild
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: roses in summer, for nuts and blackberries in autumn, and even now
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: possessing a few coral treasures in hips and haws, but whose best winter
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: delight lay in its utter solitude and leafless repose.  If a breath of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: air stirred, it made no sound here; for there was not a holly, not an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: evergreen to rustle, and the stripped hawthorn and hazel bushes were as
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: still as the white, worn stones which causewayed the middle of the path.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Far and wide, on each side, there were only fields, where no cattle now
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: browsed; and the little brown birds, which stirred occasionally in the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hedge, looked like single russet leaves that had forgotten to drop.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: This lane inclined up-hill all the way to Hay; having reached the middle,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I sat down on a stile which led thence into a field.  Gathering my mantle
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: about me, and sheltering my hands in my muff, I did not feel the cold,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: though it froze keenly; as was attested by a sheet of ice covering the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: causeway, where a little brooklet, now congealed, had overflowed after a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: rapid thaw some days since.  From my seat I could look down on
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Thornfield: the grey and battlemented hall was the principal object in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the vale below me; its woods and dark rookery rose against the west.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lingered till the sun went down amongst the trees, and sank crimson and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: clear behind them.  I then turned eastward.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: On the hill-top above me sat the rising moon; pale yet as a cloud, but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: brightening momentarily, she looked over Hay, which, half lost in trees,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sent up a blue smoke from its few chimneys: it was yet a mile distant,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: but in the absolute hush I could hear plainly its thin murmurs of life.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: My ear, too, felt the flow of currents; in what dales and depths I could
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: not tell: but there were many hills beyond Hay, and doubtless many becks
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: threading their passes.  That evening calm betrayed alike the tinkle of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the nearest streams, the sough of the most remote.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A rude noise broke on these fine ripplings and whisperings, at once so
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: far away and so clear: a positive tramp, tramp, a metallic clatter, which
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: effaced the soft wave-wanderings; as, in a picture, the solid mass of a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: crag, or the rough boles of a great oak, drawn in dark and strong on the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: foreground, efface the aerial distance of azure hill, sunny horizon, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: blended clouds where tint melts into tint.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The din was on the causeway: a horse was coming; the windings of the lane
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: yet hid it, but it approached.  I was just leaving the stile; yet, as the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: path was narrow, I sat still to let it go by.  In those days I was young,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and all sorts of fancies bright and dark tenanted my mind: the memories
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of nursery stories were there amongst other rubbish; and when they
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: recurred, maturing youth added to them a vigour and vividness beyond what
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: childhood could give.  As this horse approached, and as I watched for it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to appear through the dusk, I remembered certain of Bessie's tales,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wherein figured a North-of-England spirit called a "Gytrash," which, in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the form of horse, mule, or large dog, haunted solitary ways, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sometimes came upon belated travellers, as this horse was now coming upon
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: It was very near, but not yet in sight; when, in addition to the tramp,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: tramp, I heard a rush under the hedge, and close down by the hazel stems
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: glided a great dog, whose black and white colour made him a distinct
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: object against the trees.  It was exactly one form of Bessie's Gytrash--a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lion-like creature with long hair and a huge head: it passed me, however,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: quietly enough; not staying to look up, with strange pretercanine eyes,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in my face, as I half expected it would.  The horse followed,--a tall
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: steed, and on its back a rider.  The man, the human being, broke the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spell at once.  Nothing ever rode the Gytrash: it was always alone; and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: goblins, to my notions, though they might tenant the dumb carcasses of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: beasts, could scarce covet shelter in the commonplace human form.  No
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Gytrash was this,--only a traveller taking the short cut to Millcote.  He
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: passed, and I went on; a few steps, and I turned: a sliding sound and an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exclamation of "What the deuce is to do now?" and a clattering tumble,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: arrested my attention.  Man and horse were down; they had slipped on the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sheet of ice which glazed the causeway.  The dog came bounding back, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: seeing his master in a predicament, and hearing the horse groan, barked
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: till the evening hills echoed the sound, which was deep in proportion to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: his magnitude.  He snuffed round the prostrate group, and then he ran up
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to me; it was all he could do,--there was no other help at hand to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: summon.  I obeyed him, and walked down to the traveller, by this time
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: struggling himself free of his steed.  His efforts were so vigorous, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thought he could not be much hurt; but I asked him the question--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Are you injured, sir?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I think he was swearing, but am not certain; however, he was pronouncing
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: some formula which prevented him from replying to me directly.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Can I do anything?" I asked again.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You must just stand on one side," he answered as he rose, first to his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: knees, and then to his feet.  I did; whereupon began a heaving, stamping,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: clattering process, accompanied by a barking and baying which removed me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: effectually some yards' distance; but I would not be driven quite away
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: till I saw the event.  This was finally fortunate; the horse was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: re-established, and the dog was silenced with a "Down, Pilot!"  The
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: traveller now, stooping, felt his foot and leg, as if trying whether they
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were sound; apparently something ailed them, for he halted to the stile
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: whence I had just risen, and sat down.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I was in the mood for being useful, or at least officious, I think, for I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: now drew near him again.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "If you are hurt, and want help, sir, I can fetch some one either from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Thornfield Hall or from Hay."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Thank you: I shall do: I have no broken bones,--only a sprain;" and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: again he stood up and tried his foot, but the result extorted an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: involuntary "Ugh!"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Something of daylight still lingered, and the moon was waxing bright: I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could see him plainly.  His figure was enveloped in a riding cloak, fur
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: collared and steel clasped; its details were not apparent, but I traced
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the general points of middle height and considerable breadth of chest.  He
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had a dark face, with stern features and a heavy brow; his eyes and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: gathered eyebrows looked ireful and thwarted just now; he was past youth,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: but had not reached middle-age; perhaps he might be thirty-five.  I felt
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: no fear of him, and but little shyness.  Had he been a handsome, heroic-
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: looking young gentleman, I should not have dared to stand thus
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: questioning him against his will, and offering my services unasked.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had hardly ever seen a handsome youth; never in my life spoken to one.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had a theoretical reverence and homage for beauty, elegance, gallantry,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fascination; but had I met those qualities incarnate in masculine shape,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I should have known instinctively that they neither had nor could have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sympathy with anything in me, and should have shunned them as one would
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fire, lightning, or anything else that is bright but antipathetic.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: If even this stranger had smiled and been good-humoured to me when I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: addressed him; if he had put off my offer of assistance gaily and with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thanks, I should have gone on my way and not felt any vocation to renew
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: inquiries: but the frown, the roughness of the traveller, set me at my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ease: I retained my station when he waved to me to go, and announced--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I cannot think of leaving you, sir, at so late an hour, in this solitary
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lane, till I see you are fit to mount your horse."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: He looked at me when I said this; he had hardly turned his eyes in my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: direction before.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I should think you ought to be at home yourself," said he, "if you have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a home in this neighbourhood: where do you come from?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "From just below; and I am not at all afraid of being out late when it is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: moonlight: I will run over to Hay for you with pleasure, if you wish it:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: indeed, I am going there to post a letter."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pointing to Thornfield Hall, on which the moon cast a hoary gleam,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bringing it out distinct and pale from the woods that, by contrast with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Whose house is it?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Mr. Rochester's."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Do you know Mr. Rochester?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I cannot."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ran his eye over my dress, which, as usual, was quite simple: a black
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Ah, the governess!" he repeated; "deuce take me, if I had not forgotten!
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes, sir."

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and waiting to speak with him.

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER XVI
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER XVII
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: A week passed, and no news arrived of Mr. Rochester: ten days, and still
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: he did not come.  Mrs. Fairfax said she should not be surprised if he
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were to go straight from the Leas to London, and thence to the Continent,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: heart.  I was actually permitting myself to experience a sickening sense
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: interest.  Not that I humbled myself by a slavish notion of inferiority:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: on the contrary, I just said--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: receive the salary he gives you for teaching his protegee, and to be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grateful for such respectful and kind treatment as, if you do your duty,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: you have a right to expect at his hands.  Be sure that is the only tie he
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: seriously acknowledges between you and him; so don't make him the object
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of your fine feelings, your raptures, agonies, and so forth.  He is not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wanted and would be despised."

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the stair.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "You, madam," said he, "are cleared from all blame: your uncle will be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: glad to hear it--if, indeed, he should be still living--when Mr. Mason
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: returns to Madeira."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "My uncle!  What of him?  Do you know him?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Mr. Mason does.  Mr. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: house for some years.  When your uncle received your letter intimating
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the contemplated union between yourself and Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason, who
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was staying at Madeira to recruit his health, on his way back to Jamaica,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: happened to be with him.  Mr. Eyre mentioned the intelligence; for he
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: knew that my client here was acquainted with a gentleman of the name of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Rochester.  Mr. Mason, astonished and distressed as you may suppose,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: revealed the real state of matters.  Your uncle, I am sorry to say, is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: disease--decline--and the stage it has reached, it is unlikely he will
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ever rise.  He could not then hasten to England himself, to extricate you
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: from the snare into which you had fallen, but he implored Mr. Mason to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage.  He referred
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: him to me for assistance.  I used all despatch, and am thankful I was not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: too late: as you, doubtless, must be also.  Were I not morally certain
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that your uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, I would advise you to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: accompany Mr. Mason back; but as it is, I think you had better remain in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: England till you can hear further, either from or of Mr. Eyre.  Have we
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: anything else to stay for?" he inquired of Mr. Mason.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No, no--let us be gone," was the anxious reply; and without waiting to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I heard him go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to which
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The morning had been a quiet morning enough--all except the brief scene
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy; there
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: his idea, and from his presence I must go: _that_ I perceived well.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: conduct!
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I lay faint, longing to be dead.  One idea only still throbbed life-like
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: It was near: and as I had lifted no petition to Heaven to avert it--as I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had neither joined my hands, nor bent my knees, nor moved my lips--it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: came: in full heavy swing the torrent poured over me.  The whole
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography
