title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Gentle reader, may you never feel what I then felt!  May your eyes never
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shed such stormy, scalding, heart-wrung tears as poured from mine.  May
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: you never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that hour left my lips; for never may you, like me, dread to be the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: instrument of evil to what you wholly love.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER XXVIII
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Two days are passed.  It is a summer evening; the coachman has set me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: down at a place called Whitcross; he could take me no farther for the sum
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I had given, and I was not possessed of another shilling in the world.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The coach is a mile off by this time; I am alone.  At this moment I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: discover that I forgot to take my parcel out of the pocket of the coach,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: where I had placed it for safety; there it remains, there it must remain;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and now, I am absolutely destitute.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Whitcross is no town, nor even a hamlet; it is but a stone pillar set up
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: where four roads meet: whitewashed, I suppose, to be more obvious at a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: distance and in darkness.  Four arms spring from its summit: the nearest
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: town to which these point is, according to the inscription, distant ten
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: miles; the farthest, above twenty.  From the well-known names of these
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: towns I learn in what county I have lighted; a north-midland shire, dusk
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with moorland, ridged with mountain: this I see.  There are great moors
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: behind and on each hand of me; there are waves of mountains far beyond
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that deep valley at my feet.  The population here must be thin, and I see
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: no passengers on these roads: they stretch out east, west, north, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: south--white, broad, lonely; they are all cut in the moor, and the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: heather grows deep and wild to their very verge.  Yet a chance traveller
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: might pass by; and I wish no eye to see me now: strangers would wonder
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: what I am doing, lingering here at the sign-post, evidently objectless
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and lost.  I might be questioned: I could give no answer but what would
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sound incredible and excite suspicion.  Not a tie holds me to human
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: society at this moment--not a charm or hope calls me where my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fellow-creatures are--none that saw me would have a kind thought or a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: good wish for me.  I have no relative but the universal mother, Nature: I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: will seek her breast and ask repose.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I struck straight into the heath; I held on to a hollow I saw deeply
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: furrowing the brown moorside; I waded knee-deep in its dark growth; I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: turned with its turnings, and finding a moss-blackened granite crag in a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hidden angle, I sat down under it.  High banks of moor were about me; the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: crag protected my head: the sky was over that.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Some time passed before I felt tranquil even here: I had a vague dread
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: discover me.  If a gust of wind swept the waste, I looked up, fearing it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was the rush of a bull; if a plover whistled, I imagined it a man.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Finding my apprehensions unfounded, however, and calmed by the deep
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: silence that reigned as evening declined at nightfall, I took confidence.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: As yet I had not thought; I had only listened, watched, dreaded; now I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: regained the faculty of reflection.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: What was I to do?  Where to go?  Oh, intolerable questions, when I could
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: do nothing and go nowhere!--when a long way must yet be measured by my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: weary, trembling limbs before I could reach human habitation--when cold
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: charity must be entreated before I could get a lodging: reluctant
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sympathy importuned, almost certain repulse incurred, before my tale
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could be listened to, or one of my wants relieved!
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I touched the heath: it was dry, and yet warm with the heat of the summer
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: day.  I looked at the sky; it was pure: a kindly star twinkled just above
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the chasm ridge.  The dew fell, but with propitious softness; no breeze
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: whispered.  Nature seemed to me benign and good; I thought she loved me,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: outcast as I was; and I, who from man could anticipate only mistrust,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: rejection, insult, clung to her with filial fondness.  To-night, at
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: least, I would be her guest, as I was her child: my mother would lodge me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: without money and without price.  I had one morsel of bread yet: the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remnant of a roll I had bought in a town we passed through at noon with a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: stray penny--my last coin.  I saw ripe bilberries gleaming here and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: there, like jet beads in the heath: I gathered a handful and ate them
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with the bread.  My hunger, sharp before, was, if not satisfied, appeased
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: by this hermit's meal.  I said my evening prayers at its conclusion, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: then chose my couch.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: {I said my evening prayers: p311.jpg}
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Beside the crag the heath was very deep: when I lay down my feet were
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: buried in it; rising high on each side, it left only a narrow space for
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the night-air to invade.  I folded my shawl double, and spread it over me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for a coverlet; a low, mossy swell was my pillow.  Thus lodged, I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: not, at least--at the commencement of the night, cold.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: My rest might have been blissful enough, only a sad heart broke it.  It
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: plained of its gaping wounds, its inward bleeding, its riven chords.  It
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: trembled for Mr. Rochester and his doom; it bemoaned him with bitter
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pity; it demanded him with ceaseless longing; and, impotent as a bird
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with both wings broken, it still quivered its shattered pinions in vain
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: attempts to seek him.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Worn out with this torture of thought, I rose to my knees.  Night was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: come, and her planets were risen: a safe, still night: too serene for the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: companionship of fear.  We know that God is everywhere; but certainly we
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: feel His presence most when His works are on the grandest scale spread
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: before us; and it is in the unclouded night-sky, where His worlds wheel
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: their silent course, that we read clearest His infinitude, His
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: omnipotence, His omnipresence.  I had risen to my knees to pray for Mr.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Rochester.  Looking up, I, with tear-dimmed eyes, saw the mighty Milky-
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: way.  Remembering what it was--what countless systems there swept space
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: like a soft trace of light--I felt the might and strength of God.  Sure
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was I of His efficiency to save what He had made: convinced I grew that
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: neither earth should perish, nor one of the souls it treasured.  I turned
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my prayer to thanksgiving: the Source of Life was also the Saviour of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: spirits.  Mr. Rochester was safe; he was God's, and by God would he be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: guarded.  I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere long in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sleep forgot sorrow.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: But next day, Want came to me pale and bare.  Long after the little birds
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had left their nests; long after bees had come in the sweet prime of day
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to gather the heath honey before the dew was dried--when the long morning
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shadows were curtailed, and the sun filled earth and sky--I got up, and I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: looked round me.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: What a still, hot, perfect day!  What a golden desert this spreading
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: moor!  Everywhere sunshine.  I wished I could live in it and on it.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: saw a lizard run over the crag; I saw a bee busy among the sweet
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bilberries.  I would fain at the moment have become bee or lizard, that I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: might have found fitting nutriment, permanent shelter here.  But I was a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: human being, and had a human being's wants: I must not linger where there
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was nothing to supply them.  I rose; I looked back at the bed I had left.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Hopeless of the future, I wished but this--that my Maker had that night
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thought good to require my soul of me while I slept; and that this weary
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: frame, absolved by death from further conflict with fate, had now but to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: decay quietly, and mingle in peace with the soil of this wilderness.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Life, however, was yet in my possession, with all its requirements, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pains, and responsibilities.  The burden must be carried; the want
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: provided for; the suffering endured; the responsibility fulfilled.  I set
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: out.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Whitcross regained, I followed a road which led from the sun, now fervent
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and high.  By no other circumstance had I will to decide my choice.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: walked a long time, and when I thought I had nearly done enough, and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: might conscientiously yield to the fatigue that almost overpowered
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me--might relax this forced action, and, sitting down on a stone I saw
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: near, submit resistlessly to the apathy that clogged heart and limb--I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: heard a bell chime--a church bell.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I turned in the direction of the sound, and there, amongst the romantic
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hills, whose changes and aspect I had ceased to note an hour ago, I saw a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hamlet and a spire.  All the valley at my right hand was full of pasture-
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fields, and cornfields, and wood; and a glittering stream ran zig-zag
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: through the varied shades of green, the mellowing grain, the sombre
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: woodland, the clear and sunny lea.  Recalled by the rumbling of wheels to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the road before me, I saw a heavily-laden waggon labouring up the hill,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and not far beyond were two cows and their drover.  Human life and human
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: labour were near.  I must struggle on: strive to live and bend to toil
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: like the rest.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: About two o'clock p.m. I entered the village.  At the bottom of its one
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: street there was a little shop with some cakes of bread in the window.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: coveted a cake of bread.  With that refreshment I could perhaps regain a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: degree of energy: without it, it would be difficult to proceed.  The wish
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to have some strength and some vigour returned to me as soon as I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: amongst my fellow-beings.  I felt it would be degrading to faint with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hunger on the causeway of a hamlet.  Had I nothing about me I could offer
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: in exchange for one of these rolls?  I considered.  I had a small silk
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: handkerchief tied round my throat; I had my gloves.  I could hardly tell
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: how men and women in extremities of destitution proceeded.  I did not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: know whether either of these articles would be accepted: probably they
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: would not; but I must try.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I entered the shop: a woman was there.  Seeing a respectably-dressed
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: person, a lady as she supposed, she came forward with civility.  How
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could she serve me?  I was seized with shame: my tongue would not utter
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the request I had prepared.  I dared not offer her the half-worn gloves,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the creased handkerchief: besides, I felt it would be absurd.  I only
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: begged permission to sit down a moment, as I was tired.  Disappointed in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the expectation of a customer, she coolly acceded to my request.  She
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: pointed to a seat; I sank into it.  I felt sorely urged to weep; but
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: conscious how unseasonable such a manifestation would be, I restrained
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it.  Soon I asked her "if there were any dressmaker or plain-workwoman in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the village?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes; two or three.  Quite as many as there was employment for."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I reflected.  I was driven to the point now.  I was brought face to face
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with Necessity.  I stood in the position of one without a resource,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: without a friend, without a coin.  I must do something.  What?  I must
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: apply somewhere.  Where?
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Did she know of any place in the neighbourhood where a servant was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wanted?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Nay; she couldn't say."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "What was the chief trade in this place?  What did most of the people
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: do?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Some were farm labourers; a good deal worked at Mr. Oliver's
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: needle-factory, and at the foundry."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Did Mr. Oliver employ women?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Nay; it was men's work."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And what do the women do?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I knawn't," was the answer.  "Some does one thing, and some another.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Poor folk mun get on as they can."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: She seemed to be tired of my questions: and, indeed, what claim had I to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: importune her?  A neighbour or two came in; my chair was evidently
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wanted.  I took leave.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I passed up the street, looking as I went at all the houses to the right
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hand and to the left; but I could discover no pretext, nor see an
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: inducement to enter any.  I rambled round the hamlet, going sometimes to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a little distance and returning again, for an hour or more.  Much
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exhausted, and suffering greatly now for want of food, I turned aside
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: into a lane and sat down under the hedge.  Ere many minutes had elapsed,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I was again on my feet, however, and again searching something--a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: resource, or at least an informant.  A pretty little house stood at the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: top of the lane, with a garden before it, exquisitely neat and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: brilliantly blooming.  I stopped at it.  What business had I to approach
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the white door or touch the glittering knocker?  In what way could it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: possibly be the interest of the inhabitants of that dwelling to serve me?
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Yet I drew near and knocked.  A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: opened the door.  In such a voice as might be expected from a hopeless
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: heart and fainting frame--a voice wretchedly low and faltering--I asked
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: if a servant was wanted here?
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No," said she; "we do not keep a servant."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Can you tell me where I could get employment of any kind?" I continued.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "I am a stranger, without acquaintance in this place.  I want some work:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: no matter what."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: But it was not her business to think for me, or to seek a place for me:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: besides, in her eyes, how doubtful must have appeared my character,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: position, tale.  She shook her head, she "was sorry she could give me no
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: information," and the white door closed, quite gently and civilly: but it
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: shut me out.  If she had held it open a little longer, I believe I should
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: have begged a piece of bread; for I was now brought low.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I could not bear to return to the sordid village, where, besides, no
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: prospect of aid was visible.  I should have longed rather to deviate to a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wood I saw not far off, which appeared in its thick shade to offer
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: inviting shelter; but I was so sick, so weak, so gnawed with nature's
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: cravings, instinct kept me roaming round abodes where there was a chance
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: of food.  Solitude would be no solitude--rest no rest--while the vulture,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hunger, thus sank beak and talons in my side.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I drew near houses; I left them, and came back again, and again I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: wandered away: always repelled by the consciousness of having no claim to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ask--no right to expect interest in my isolated lot.  Meantime, the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: afternoon advanced, while I thus wandered about like a lost and starving
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dog.  In crossing a field, I saw the church spire before me: I hastened
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: towards it.  Near the churchyard, and in the middle of a garden, stood a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: well-built though small house, which I had no doubt was the parsonage.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remembered that strangers who arrive at a place where they have no
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: friends, and who want employment, sometimes apply to the clergyman for
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: introduction and aid.  It is the clergyman's function to help--at least
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: with advice--those who wished to help themselves.  I seemed to have
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: something like a right to seek counsel here.  Renewing then my courage,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: and gathering my feeble remains of strength, I pushed on.  I reached the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: house, and knocked at the kitchen-door.  An old woman opened: I asked was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: this the parsonage?
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Yes."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Was the clergyman in?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Would he be in soon?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No, he was gone from home."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "To a distance?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Not so far--happen three mile.  He had been called away by the sudden
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: death of his father: he was at Marsh End now, and would very likely stay
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: there a fortnight longer."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Was there any lady of the house?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Nay, there was naught but her, and she was housekeeper;" and of her,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: reader, I could not bear to ask the relief for want of which I was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sinking; I could not yet beg; and again I crawled away.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Once more I took off my handkerchief--once more I thought of the cakes of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bread in the little shop.  Oh, for but a crust! for but one mouthful to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: allay the pang of famine!  Instinctively I turned my face again to the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: village; I found the shop again, and I went in; and though others were
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: there besides the woman I ventured the request--"Would she give me a roll
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for this handkerchief?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: She looked at me with evident suspicion: "Nay, she never sold stuff i'
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: that way."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Almost desperate, I asked for half a cake; she again refused.  "How could
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: she tell where I had got the handkerchief?" she said.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "Would she take my gloves?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "No! what could she do with them?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Reader, it is not pleasant to dwell on these details.  Some say there is
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: enjoyment in looking back to painful experience past; but at this day I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: can scarcely bear to review the times to which I allude: the moral
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: degradation, blent with the physical suffering, form too distressing a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: recollection ever to be willingly dwelt on.  I blamed none of those who
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: repulsed me.  I felt it was what was to be expected, and what could not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be helped: an ordinary beggar is frequently an object of suspicion; a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: well-dressed beggar inevitably so.  To be sure, what I begged was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: employment; but whose business was it to provide me with employment?  Not,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: certainly, that of persons who saw me then for the first time, and who
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: knew nothing about my character.  And as to the woman who would not take
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: my handkerchief in exchange for her bread, why, she was right, if the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: offer appeared to her sinister or the exchange unprofitable.  Let me

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: few thoughts framed, and no actions performed.  I knew I was in a small
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: CHAPTER XXXVII
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.  I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: had heard of it before.  Mr. Rochester often spoke of it, and sometimes
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: went there.  His father had purchased the estate for the sake of the game
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: covers.  He would have let the house, but could find no tenant, in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site.  Ferndean then
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception of some two or
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the squire when he went
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: there in the season to shoot.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: driver with the double remuneration I had promised.  Even when within a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing of it, so
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it.  Iron gates
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and passing through
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: them, I found myself at once in the twilight of close-ranked trees.  There
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: was a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: knotty shafts and under branched arches.  I followed it, expecting soon
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on and on, it wound far and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was visible.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way.  The darkness of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: search of another road.  There was none: all was interwoven stem,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: columnar trunk, dense summer foliage--no opening anywhere.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little; presently
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I beheld a railing, then the house--scarce, by this dim light,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: distinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: walls.  Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a semicircle.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of the forest.  The house
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: presented two pointed gables in its front; the windows were latticed and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the forest leaves was the only sound audible in its vicinage.

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grange.

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: has maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever since:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: he hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live without God in
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the world, and only mind earthly things.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: You have not quite forgotten little Adele, have you, reader?  I had not;
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I soon asked and obtained leave of Mr. Rochester, to go and see her at
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the school where he had placed her.  Her frantic joy at beholding me
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: again moved me much.  She looked pale and thin: she said she was not
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: happy.  I found the rules of the establishment were too strict, its
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: course of study too severe for a child of her age: I took her home with
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: me.  I meant to become her governess once more, but I soon found this
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: impracticable; my time and cares were now required by another--my husband
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: needed them all.  So I sought out a school conducted on a more indulgent
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: system, and near enough to permit of my visiting her often, and bringing
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: her home sometimes.  I took care she should never want for anything that
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could contribute to her comfort: she soon settled in her new abode,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: became very happy there, and made fair progress in her studies.  As she
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grew up, a sound English education corrected in a great measure her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: French defects; and when she left school, I found in her a pleasing and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: obliging companion: docile, good-tempered, and well-principled.  By her
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: grateful attention to me and mine, she has long since well repaid any
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: little kindness I ever had it in my power to offer her.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: My tale draws to its close: one word respecting my experience of married
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names have most
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: frequently recurred in this narrative, and I have done.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I have now been married ten years.  I know what it is to live entirely
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: for and with what I love best on earth.  I hold myself supremely
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: blest--blest beyond what language can express; because I am my husband's
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: life as fully as he is mine.  No woman was ever nearer to her mate than I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: am: ever more absolutely bone of his bone and flesh of his flesh.  I know
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: no weariness of my Edward's society: he knows none of mine, any more than
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: we each do of the pulsation of the heart that beats in our separate
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: bosoms; consequently, we are ever together.  To be together is for us to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be at once as free as in solitude, as gay as in company.  We talk, I
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: believe, all day long: to talk to each other is but a more animated and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: an audible thinking.  All my confidence is bestowed on him, all his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: confidence is devoted to me; we are precisely suited in character--perfect
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: concord is the result.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Mr. Rochester continued blind the first two years of our union; perhaps
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: it was that circumstance that drew us so very near--that knit us so very
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: close: for I was then his vision, as I am still his right hand.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Literally, I was (what he often called me) the apple of his eye.  He saw
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: nature--he saw books through me; and never did I weary of gazing for his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: behalf, and of putting into words the effect of field, tree, town, river,
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: cloud, sunbeam--of the landscape before us; of the weather round us--and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: impressing by sound on his ear what light could no longer stamp on his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: eye.  Never did I weary of reading to him; never did I weary of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: conducting him where he wished to go: of doing for him what he wished to
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: be done.  And there was a pleasure in my services, most full, most
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: exquisite, even though sad--because he claimed these services without
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: painful shame or damping humiliation.  He loved me so truly, that he knew
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: no reluctance in profiting by my attendance: he felt I loved him so
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fondly, that to yield that attendance was to indulge my sweetest wishes.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: One morning at the end of the two years, as I was writing a letter to his
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: dictation, he came and bent over me, and said--"Jane, have you a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: glittering ornament round your neck?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I had a gold watch-chain: I answered "Yes."
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "And have you a pale blue dress on?"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: {And have you a pale blue dress on?: p435.jpg}
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: I had.  He informed me then, that for some time he had fancied the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: obscurity clouding one eye was becoming less dense; and that now he was
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sure of it.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: He and I went up to London.  He had the advice of an eminent oculist; and
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: he eventually recovered the sight of that one eye.  He cannot now see
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: very distinctly: he cannot read or write much; but he can find his way
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: without being led by the hand: the sky is no longer a blank to him--the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: earth no longer a void.  When his first-born was put into his arms, he
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: could see that the boy had inherited his own eyes, as they once
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: were--large, brilliant, and black.  On that occasion, he again, with a
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: My Edward and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those we most
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: love are happy likewise.  Diana and Mary Rivers are both married:
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: alternately, once every year, they come to see us, and we go to see them.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Diana's husband is a captain in the navy, a gallant officer and a good
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: man.  Mary's is a clergyman, a college friend of her brother's, and, from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: his attainments and principles, worthy of the connection.  Both Captain
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton love their wives, and are loved by them.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: As to St. John Rivers, he left England: he went to India.  He entered on
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the path he had marked for himself; he pursues it still.  A more
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: resolute, indefatigable pioneer never wrought amidst rocks and dangers.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: Firm, faithful, and devoted, full of energy, and zeal, and truth, he
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: labours for his race; he clears their painful way to improvement; he hews
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: down like a giant the prejudices of creed and caste that encumber it.  He
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: may be stern; he may be exacting; he may be ambitious yet; but his is the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sternness of the warrior Greatheart, who guards his pilgrim convoy from
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the onslaught of Apollyon.  His is the exaction of the apostle, who
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: speaks but for Christ, when he says--"Whosoever will come after me, let
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: him deny himself, and take up his cross and follow me."  His is the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: ambition of the high master-spirit, which aims to fill a place in the
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: first rank of those who are redeemed from the earth--who stand without
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fault before the throne of God, who share the last mighty victories of
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: the Lamb, who are called, and chosen, and faithful.
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: St. John is unmarried: he never will marry now.  Himself has hitherto
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: sufficed to the toil, and the toil draws near its close: his glorious sun
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: hastens to its setting.  The last letter I received from him drew from my
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: eyes human tears, and yet filled my heart with divine joy: he anticipated
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: his sure reward, his incorruptible crown.  I know that a stranger's hand
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: will write to me next, to say that the good and faithful servant has been
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: called at length into the joy of his Lord.  And why weep for this?  No
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: fear of death will darken St. John's last hour: his mind will be
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: unclouded, his heart will be undaunted, his hope will be sure, his faith
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: steadfast.  His own words are a pledge of this--
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: "My Master," he says, "has forewarned me.  Daily He announces more
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: distinctly,--'Surely I come quickly!' and hourly I more eagerly
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography

text: respond,--'Amen; even so come, Lord Jesus!'"
title: Jane Eyre: An Autobiography
